sourceDesc.p: TEI-page files converted by Python to TEI-entry file

div.p: STILL, John (c. 1543-1607), bishop of Bath and Wells, and now best known as the probable author (“Mr S., Master of Arts ”) of Gammer Gurioris Needle, the earliest comedy but one in the English language (see Drama, vol. vii. p. 428), was a native of Grantham, Lincolnshire, and

unknown title unknown author unknown date <,date> <,edition> <,editionStmt> unknown <,p> Converted from a Word document with eb-docx2tei. <,p> Knowledge Project: DOCX to TEI <,application> <,appInfo> <,encodingDesc> 2OI9-OI-2OT22:4I:4OZ <,date> unknown author <,name> <,change> <,listChange> <,revisionDesc> was born about I543. He became a student of Christ’s College, Cambridge, where he duly graduated and took orders. He was appointed in I57O Lady Margaret’s professor of divinity in his university, subsequently held livings in Suffolk and Yorkshire, and was master successively of St John’s College (I574) and of Trinity College (I577). Still was raised to the bishopric of Bath and Wells in I592, and, after enjoying considerable fame as a preacher and disputant, he died on February 26, I6O7, leaving a large fortune from lead mines discovered in the Mendip Hills. <,p> <,div>
